text: in Iraq three more protesters have been
killed today as demonstrators continue
their campaign for new elections and an
end to corruption most of the protesters
are young Iraqis who want an end to
American and Iranian interference in the
country more than 500 people have been
killed by security forces and pro-union
militia during months of demonstrations
a Middle East correspondent Quentin
Somerville and cameraman Nick Millard
have spent the past few days following
the protesters in Baghdad
iraq is both a country in a gridlock and
coming apart of the series four months
young Iraqis have been on the streets
intent on sweeping away the old guard
they say their government isn't
listening so these young Iraqis are
piling on the pressure here in Baghdad
and in cities across Iraq they say that
the man's will be forgotten and our
protest won't end it already brought
down the last government but it's not
enough in a country of fierce division
Eve emerged United Sunni Shia Christian
rich and poor we won't arrive like the
life others have in Europe America and
elsewhere our own politicians who are
not mean who are supported by Iran Saudi
or the United States but old Iraq hasn't
vanished
nearly 500 protestors have died killed
by security forces and pro orany militia
since October
today's push is to bring Iraq to a
standstill

we want a new Prime Minister and fresh

these protests may look familiar but
they're not they transcend social class
and religious sect not on their scale
make them unprecedented for Iraq the
odds are stacked against these young
people but they say they have no choice
their lives and the future depend on
what happens on these streets so tonight
they're back at the barricades resisting
